column11: Review Text

This used to be one of the loveliest spots in Sri Lanka to kick back, swim and observe turtles And while it is still lovely looking I was horrified to see people encouraging interaction with wild turtles. This is wrong on so many levels. Encouraging wild animals to associate humans with food is only going to end badly for both parties. I found the experience of watching people sell plastic (of course) bags of seaweed to idiot tourists feed and touch (and take selfies) with the turtles so distressing that I am not sure I want to go back. Dear Sri Lanka - Yala was spoilt (although well done for your recent efforts to encourage licences and proper behaviours) please don‚Äôt let marine habitats go the same way. And tourists. Behave yourselves!
Beautiful beach with clean water. Safe and nice atmosphere. Less crowded. You can see turtles also.
It‚Äôs beautiful at this beach. You can swim in the lagoon with turtles which is just amazing. Our hotel was right on this beach and we love it.

Depends on when you go to the beach, as to how you will rate it. Go on the morning and the beach is quiet, the sea is calm from the  natural tide breakers from the arch shaped rocks. There's not too many people around and you are likely to see some turtles swimming in the inlet. Go late morning onwards and there's loads more people, the sea gets choppier and some people are chasing the turtles. It's their habitat not ours and people are damaging them by touching them. Their shells are going white from touching and it's slowly killing them. If you see one, look but don't touch. It's a lovely beach and well looked after but it's being spoilt by too many tourists being allowed. We came away early because of this. You can hire 2 sunbeds and an umbrella for 1000rupees which is good value.

Beautiful beach, crystal clear warm waters and MANY TURTLES!! Take a snorkeling gear with you when visiting. Beware of strong currents in the west side of the beach. The eastern area is calm and great for snorkel. Friendly reminder: do NOT touch the animals and DON'T surround them (this is advised all over the beach but some people forget the basics)

Beautiful beach, with a large protected lagoon at the Galle end of the beach, where we had regular close encounters with turtles.  1000rs secures two sunbeds and shade for the day, which is ideal as the beach itself is not very wide. By using the beds by the Wijaya Beach Pizza Restaurant you place yourself directly in front of the main swimming area.
Not much known among the crowd but very clean and seductive beach . Picturesque and long waves , but not recommended for bathing
it is also popular and perfect place,no crowded beach,beautiful weather,we enjoyed the bar on the beach,

If, like us, you love the natural world and seeing animals in the wild don‚Äôt go here. The lagoon is full of ignorant tourists crowding turtles and trying to get selfies to boost their Instagram likes. This needs to be better regulated as the signs on the beach are simply ignored. Our hotel owner tells us two turtles drowned here recently due to tourists holding them underwater for photos.

This beach! I still have it as wallpaper on my mobile. There is a small natural pool with not so deep water, but be careful if you go on the ocean, there are strong currents. We saw turtles, we enjoyed the bar on the beach, it is a perfect place!

What a fantastic place, the lagoon is huge and brilliant for kids and beginner snorkelers. At the entrance water is rough and deep and that is where the turtles come in. We sat in the water for a few hours, floating along the rocky edges in our snorkels watching the fish, eels go about there business. It is annoying when everyone chases the turtles around rather than let them come to you!! Restaurants along the beach here are good. A make shift cafe at the far end for a breeze and lounger on the sand.

The swing on Dallawella Beach is a MUST! You get to swing in the air from a palm tree over the sand and ocean, in beautiful surroundings. The people who works there are also so chill and helpful if you‚Äôre a little afraid. Put in on your bucketlist - YOLO :)
We fed wild sea turtles here with ht elocal plants andf they are so cute and placid to walk around with inthe small bay

Definitely good spot for a travel pic but not necessarily as hidden and dreamy as promoted. Had to pay 500lk to do the swing and had to take a turn in very low season after the attacks (so no tourists in sight apart from us)

We were in Sri Lanka and the kids found this palm tree swing online at Dalawella beach.   It‚Äôs located behind the Dream Cabana hotel which is a fairly low end hotel right on the beach.  The owner charges a fee to use the swing and he told us the reason he charges is because people use the swing and don‚Äôt get off of it.  So, now he charges Rs 500 per person but you get 3 rides on the swing for that.  In US dollars that is just under $3, so I was perfectly fine with paying.  This is an example of social media blowing up a little tree swing and making a local guy a lot of extra money, good for him, I support it.  My teenage kids had a great time for few bucks. The other way to get access to the swing is purchase some drinks and they will let you ride the swing. Note - we visited in June so the sea was very rough.  It‚Äôs ok because you get off the swing on the beach.  If you want to go to this place when the sea is calm, you need to visit between December and March.
Dalawella beach is really a soft beach. Recommended by a friend, I paid a visit to this beach interestingly it seemed out to be good. I would recommend you but there are some better options :)
Have no words to explain this beautiful beach . It was raining when we went there and the beach swing is the main attraction.
When we were there the beach was not crowded, no litter on it. The water is very calm, good for swimming. There are sunbeds for rent. 15 min bus ride from Galle. We really enjoyed our time there.

This beach is amazing.  Breath taking and beautiful.  The rope swing was really good and our teenager loved it. We had pizza from the famous oven and that was good too. Not far by tuk tuk from Galle. lovely afternoon out.

Dalawella Beach is about 10 minutes away from Unawatuna by tuk-tuk. The beach is protected by a reef about 50 meters out in the sea which form a very nice lagoon. In this lagoon we saw at least two large turtles swimming around. At the beach it is possible to rent a sunbed for 500LKR a day.
Great little beach with a nice surf break. Fun little pizza place with drinks. And everyone has to have a go on the famous rope swing.

This is hands down 1 of the best beaches I‚Äôve ever been on. Absolutely beautiful, soft sand, clear water, mixed crowds with good food and drinks. It has a swinging rope with giant turtles swimming around. I didn‚Äôt want to leave here.

We went here for seeing the famous rock that we saw in almost alot of sri lanka beaches photos. We were shocked coz the rock was really thin in width but had hight. The one couldnt go easily to top. We just relax near to it and had our lunch the restuarant near to the rock.

Almost forgot to write about this beach because it is so tranquil. It is such a nice place to enjoy - away from the crowds and touts hat come with tourist beaches. Not sure how long it will stay this way but enjoy it while you can.

Located on the very popular southern coastal region near Galle, Sri Lanka this beachside area attracts backpackers, surfers and those just wanting a great beach to relax or sun bathe on. It is very clean with a good sandy beach.

I‚Äôd read before going to Sri Lanka that bikinis are acceptable at the beach, especially in towns where there are many tourists such as Galle. However, after fifteen minutes at the beach in standard bikinis, an entire family that just arrived stared at us for a good five minutes before four men came up to us demanding that we leave due to cultural differences. The experience was extremely uncomfortable. I hate to be culturally insensitive so I had done research beforehand. But apparently the countless photos I saw online of bikini-clad girls, blogs‚Äô advice, and commenters‚Äô reassurances were mistaken. What baffles me even more is that bikinis are sold in many shops in Galle to tourists yet they are not allowed to wear them.

This is one of our favorite beaches so far in Sri Lanka. From the cleanliness to the relaxing vibe this place has it all. It has amazing sites, iconic picture spots and if you go at the right time it even has HUGE sea turtles. Highly recommend this beach and dont think you should miss it!

One of the best beaches in Srilanka. If you are visiting Galle please do visit this beach. Add to the bucket list and don't miss this scenic beauty.. You can experience the swing on coconut tree, which is very much bent naturally due to sunlight. Try this beach in early morning and early evening. Very much suitable for photography. 9/10
really nice beach but be warned there was a lovely breeze which seemed to be there all the time but this can cause you to get complacent and miss the sunscreen easy to get burnt
Was nice to see a different beach. Decent overall. Good stretch of beach to walk along. The swing is pretty neat. If you go, be sure to wait until the sun has set to get the best pictures.
Many of the beaches were unsuitable for swimming or those who can‚Äôt swim. This beautiful beach has a reef which creates a natural swimming pool.
very nice beach great for walks nice lagoon bit with shallow waters watch big waves break on reef have a swing on rope if you want nice restaurant on beach

Famed for the swing, we got a tuktuk from Unawatuna for 250LKR. Not that obvious on how to get on to the beach, with the majority of the beach being taken up with resorts but there's a few small alleys that give access. Really nice, calmer beach than Mirissa and Unawatuna. 500LKR for the tree swing, and we got a drink at the place next to it to relax and enjoy it.
really lovely beach with some shade under the palms if you don't want to use the sun beds.  Couple of places to also eat on the beach.  one does pizza's in open oven which are lovely.
another lovely beach, close to the road but nonetheless, very good. not too busy on the day we went, so even better in my eyes

We had visited this area 25 years ago and time has not been kind to it.The charming simple way of life has been replaced by commercial exploitation but I suppose the same could be said for many other places.
Just a nice thing to do in the late afternoon and take beautiful pictures! Costs 500LKR for 3 swings.
A much smaller beach than Unawatuna Beach. Plenty of space to spread out. Beach Chairs available to rent at 500 Rupees. A couple of good beach bars serving food, beer and juice.

Pros - Amazing water, great for swimming. Got a chance to swim with two large turtles which was one of my favourite moments in Sri Lanka. Right next a pizza place which is a good lunch option. Safe swimming area for children. Snorkles and masks easy to hire for 500 rupees which you can keep for the day. Lovely people. Cons - little bit rocky but safe if you are cautious. Small current. Bit overcrowded but if you walk past the rocks there is a nothing section which is pretty much secluded. Lovely beach. Great for kids. Will come again. :-)

It's a cute picturesque spot to relax, you could get a sun lounger from nearby hotels Wijaya, and another one closeby. The beach itself was very quite, not crowded and no annoying vendors. The waves were a bit too strong there for swimming but OK for a quick dip, and also turtle spotting. Turtles come up to graze on the seagrass there, you might see them popping their heads up for a quick breath, but not seen them on the beach itself laying eggs. Some people snorkel to get a closer look of the turtles, but be ware of the slippery rocks at the bottom and strong wave current. The sandy stretch is great for strolling to the nearby rock, beautiful sunset, nice setting.

this beach has soft sand and long stretch , where you can walk and nice sunset. Slightly less crowded compare to other. Nice place to swim as tides are stopped by the rocks so overall great experience here. Now comes to Rope Swing , which is disgusting . you dont know does the rope will last long so check before taking the risk and they will charge you 300rs and there is ship rock which is nice for photographs.

Nice beach area with good and different popular stops like Swing Rope, Ship Rock on the entire stretch of Dalawella Beach. Beach is obviously clean and some part has rocks where you can sit and enjoy the sunset views. Try to go as far as possible as then only you will find these cute little spots perfect for your picture and making memories.
This beach is slightly less visited hence less nosiy. Famous for nice sand, low water, swimming experience with turtles and palm tree rope swings.

Can't really review the beach itself, but I stopped by here quickly for the Rope Swing ... it's obviously a pretty cool thing, but the guys operating it were dodgy. They said it'd be 300 rupees for a go; I only had 1000 note, so paid them this ... then they said they had no change on them. I said, I want my 700 ... they "sent someone into town" to get the change ... they were clearly hoping I'd get bored and would wander off. So I waited. I had to wait there about 15min before I eventually got my change. This took the sheen off the experience ... be careful. I'd only do this if you had exact change. The fact you need to pay for it in the first place is a joke.

This is such a fabulous beach and so happy we stayed here and not Unawatuna. There is a lovely lagoon that is very child friendly and this is a great place to turtle watch üòç I would definitely advise you to bring your own snorkel and goggles-we had a very unpleasant experience with the guys that you can rent from. They guys were still setting up for the day so we on and off the beach. Our snorkel wasn‚Äôt working so we just shared one set-when the guys came back onto the beach we let him know and wanted a refund for the one set as we couldn‚Äôt and didn‚Äôt use it. He outright refused and said we are lying as he saw us both snorkelling. It was very unpleasant and he was the rudest Sri Lankan we have met on our entire trip. Other than that, it‚Äôs a wonderful beach!

A little too quiet for my liking of a beach resort. There's no shops or restaurants within walking distance. Breakfast is pricey at USD10 per pax. We decided to go into Galle town for breakfast instead. Rooms were basic and clean. Mattress and pillows not too comfy. Coffee /tea making facilities available.
Spent a fruitful day in the sands of this glamorous place. Safe and finest bathing area surrounded by reefs. yet unspoilt.

If you want a Perfect "Cover Photo" to your Social Media account, This is the best place to have it. Dalawella Beach became very popular with awesome Coconut Palm Tree Rope Swing. So dont miss if you go to Dalawella or Unawatuna. If you are a traveler a must-visit spot and dont forget to record / capture your swing. Ideal for evening as you can capture your swing with Sun Set. You have to Pay LKR / Rs 500 to get the rope for a swing. Famous Unawatuna beach very close to Dalawella. This palm coconut tree situated near Galle-Matara A2 main road, So if you are passing it you can visit this place. Few steps towards beach.
Dulan has a good fim, honest and good cars and drivers , the driver show me a part the country and i love it

Me and my husband went to srilanka for vacation and we visited galle face beach with our friends and family. good place for kids as well. You can find a mouthwatering seafood restaurants along the beach.shops open selling toys and souveniers. Kids playing around and enjoying the vicinity. Beautiful stunning hotels as well facing the beach.

What started as a simple leisure for the locals became famous tourist must-do and one of the top-most instagrammable activities in Sri Lanka.  6 months of waiting and we finally got there today, swinging.  What made it more satisfying was the fact that my 6-year old son did it too without a hint of fear!  A thrill-seeker boy.  Though he swam with the sharks few months ago, today marks the confirmation that this proud-chubby-mama now has a partner in all the future daring adventures. WHAT:  The Palm-Swing WHERE: Unawatuna Beach, District of Galle DISTANCE FROM COLOMBO: 2-hour drive TRANSPORTATION: Private car arrangement NEAREST LANDMARK:  Dalawella Beach Resort COST:  LKR500 per person TIP:  Try to haggle.  The locals attending the swing are very nice and considerate especially if you are a big group.  Thirst-quenchers are sold at LKR300/drink & you can enjoy your drinks at the open hut right at the foot of the palm where the rope swing is.  Or if chilling on the sand is what you‚Äôd like,  that‚Äôs an option too.

Perfect beach, soft sands, picturesque. Quiet, with few people around. Food at Wijaya Beach restaurant was great. Seeing turtles in the sheltered parts of the bay was an added bonus! About 10km south of Galle fort (Tuktuk 600-800 LKR one way).
A lovely and clean beach.  not too many visitors, so you could feel relaxed without the crowds.  was only there for a day. worth it.

A beautiful beach, made even better by the chance to swim with giant turtles - one of the best experiences of my life! They really are giant and you can get very close to these amazing creatures. The tide goes out to form a lagoon, so it's a nice place to swim for kids.
Loved the beach, swim in the cool rock pool watching surfers. Just stunning. We had just completed a cycle with Idle Bikes whose base is nearby. There is a yoga Shala there and s delish Cafe.

I went there to watch turtles and  saw  one, but huge. Better go with snorkeling equipment.  The beach itself was so nice, water clean, warm and calm, so we spent there several hours in water. Be aware of sunburn you can get while swimming. There is a rope to swing on it, you can take picturesque shots.

This is a great beach for kids, as the (dead by now) coral reef forms a natural shallow ‚Äúswimming pool‚Äù at the eastern part of the beach.  The western part has strong waves and seems to be a good place for surfers.  Unfortunately (for me), neither part is good for real swimming ‚Äì the eastern part is way too shallow for this, and the western part has pretty strong currents.  Also, the beach must have become very popular this season, as there are lots of people here; the admittedly more touristy nearby Unawatuna beach is much less crowded these days.  Finally, there is little choice of restaurants here, which may be the reason for surprisingly high (compared to Unawatuna and ‚Äì even more so ‚Äì to Hikkaduwa) prices.  Overall, and given the other reviews, I was rather disappointed by this place and I wished I booked a hotel in Unawatuna (which is only 5 minutes / 200 rupees by tuk tuk away) instead.

Beautiful unspoilt beach. One end used by surfers and currents quite strong, the other has a small, calm lagoon sheltered by coral and where turtles often come in to feed at high tide. Snorkelling doesn't compare to Egypt, water can be cloudy, but swimming with giant turtles makes it special. Couple of nice beach restaurants to eat. Very quiet and unspoilt.

Well worth visiting, take a tuktuk to Wijaya beach restaurant and walk through the restaurant to the beach. It's a much nicer beach than Unawatuna,  soft sand, palm trees, stilt fishermen and the famous tree swing if you walk to the right end, and if you head to the left end, a sheltered lagoon area that has turtles in, feeding on seaweed and they are happy to take weed from your hand

While we love the ocean and swim, snorkle and dive a lot we aren't really into the tanning thing;-). But Dalawella beach is the best of the three we have been on in Sri Lanka (Una, Hikka and Dala). The reef creates a great protected natural pool that's great for kids. On the right hand side there are good spots for pretty pics of "GF on rocks with Palm Trees" if you're into that stuff;-). Further right you have some locals fishing on stilts but bear in mind they are really tired of tourists snapping away at them and will likely expect a tip or you'll get yelled at. Up to you how to deal with that.

Palm tree swing is the best activity here. This place was got popular from Instagram viral photos of beach swing. You can find few restaurants here. my advice is you should visit this beach before it is getting to crowded and popular . beach is great clean and slow waves. Good place to spend an evening in a beach in Sri Lanka

Perhaps the best beach we have been on in Sri Lanka. It has the nicest sand and a rather large natural pool and perfect for the kids in low tide - quiet waters and no current. A reef stops the waves. When tide is coming large sea turtles will enter the pool for eating. You can swim beside them. Great experience for the kids and adults of course. Bring Your own towel or rent a sunbed and umbrella for 500 rupees per item. 4-5 places for food including a really pizza place. Great food, great drinks and a really good vibe. At the same time this is an access to the beach - look for "Wijaya Beach". All tuk-tuk-drives knows it and You can easily get to and from the place in the evening.

We‚Äôre lucky to have a rental villa which is situated right on this lovely beach. The sand is soft and clean, the sea a beautiful colour & hardly any people! The sea is quite rough, but there‚Äôs a lagoon just a short walk along the beach for really safe swimming. Having just visited Unawatuna beach, this one is so much nicer (& cleaner).
Used this beach loads on our recent holiday to Unawatuna as it‚Äôs much better than the main beach, it was a half hour walk for us, but worth it.

I don't know where public access is but I was dropped off at Wijaya and walked through, then sat on a sunbed with no one ever coming to get payment (500, same at all the places).  Overwhelmingly westerners and seemed completely safe to leave your stuff lying around.  The sand is nice and pretty clean, while there's a 1m-2m deep area going about 50m out that's protected from the waves by a reef.  Not much snorkelling even out towards the reef.  Sunset views.
This is a very good beach just out of the tourist area.A very good place for a sea bath.This is about 20 minutes from the centre.
What a beautiful little bay, has a  sheltered swimming area to the left of the beach, sheltered by a reef . Not much shade on this beach unfortunately.
Great little beach without the crowds of Unawatuna, and has lots of turtles popping up to say hello. Some nice places to eat along the beach too.

Unawatuna is just such an ugly experience, but 2 km down the road (200 rupees by tuk tuk) you have beautiful Dalawella beach, which is what we expected from a tropical beach. Lovely turquoise water, plenty of palm trees, safe swimming by the left hand side (especially during the morning), several bars that rent sun lounges cheaply, palm swings at either side of the beach for 200 rupees. We even saw giant turtles! Enjoy it! But careful with the ripe currents when not swimming in the "safe" area!

It is a brilliant little haven about 10-20 minutes from the main tourist beach; Unawatuna. It is pretty quiet and the sea life is amazing. In the sea areas we could still stand up in, we saw beautiful colourful fish, a shoal of about 500 mini silver fish and even two giant turtles! There's a few nice restaurants and great rock pools two. Something to do for the whole family.

We are staying at Unawatuna and so disappointed by the beach here - we were told that after the tsunami they brought out sand from Colombo to fill up the beach, it‚Äôs currently full of horrible sand and lots of litter in the beach as well as the water. We decided to day trip down to Dalawella beach which is only 10 minutes tuk tuk and what a find! The beach has formed a little cove which is great for relaxing, swimming and also cuts the strong waves from the ocean here. There are also areas for surfing, but they are near rocks so probably best for more advanced surfers. Not too many people here, very suitable for children. We also brought our snorkel gear here and what a treat! Lots of little and big fish in the coral as well as SEA TURTLE! We saw a very relaxed pregnant female in the calm waters! What a great find! This is my favourite beach in Sri Lanka!
dalawella beach is good beach that i ever seen in sri lanka.it have cool screen in sunset.i like to see fish in that place and walk in the beach.i collect sea shell from the beach.

A great place to "escape" to for a few hours or even a day if you are staying in Galle for a few days. Hidden between two popular beaches, the extremely busy Unawatuna beach and perhaps the slightly less popular Talpe Beach, is Dalawella beach. Dug our feet in to the soft sandy beach, swam a little, tried a rope-ride tied to a coconut tree by some local children, lay on our towels all day long... ah... simply magic.
